docs.lead_paragraph: A hormonal drug used for 10 years to help infertile women was approved yesterday by the Food and Drug Administration for use by men with fertility problems. The drug, human menopausal gonadotropins, will be manufactured and distributed under the trade name Pergonal by Serono Laboratories in Braintree, Mass. It has been found to be effective in treating men suffering from a pituitary deficiency that prevents them from fathering children.

headline.main: U.S. APPROVES MEN'S USE OF DRUG TO HELP FERTILITY

docs.lead_paragraph: THOUGH it was not realized at the time, vitamin C was the subject of the first controlled clinical experiment on record. In the 1750's, a British physician named James Lind showed that by including limes in sea rations, the debilitating symptoms of scurvy - the vitamin C deficiency disease - could be prevented. Those sailors given limes stayed free of scurvy despite lengthy voyages during which there was precious little fresh food; those deprived of limes got the classic symptoms: loss of appetite, bleeding gums, degenerating muscles, wounds that won't heal, dry rough skin. Hence arose the custom of supplying citrus fruits on long voyages and the popular name for British sailors, ''limeys.'' More than two centuries later the Nobel laureate Linus Pauling once a gain swept v itamin C into prominance with his enthusiastic endorsement o f its supposed ability to ward off and diminish the severity of t he common cold.

docs.lead_paragraph: AMONMOUTH COUNTY developer has received preliminary approval from the state's Department of Environmental Protection to build a 200-unit condominium and marina complex on Shark River Island in Neptune Township. According to the D.E.P. and the developer, Kaufman & Broad Homes Inc. of Manalapan, some of the building units will be 50 feet from state-protected wetlands within the Shark River Basin, along Route 35. The area, which is said to be one of the most biologically productive small estuaries along the New Jersey coast, is the winter home of diverse species of waterfowl. Daniel Murphy, the company's vice president for planning, said that ''extra precautions'' would be taken to protect the area and its wildlife. ''In no way will we be destroying wetlands, and we wouldn't even if we were allowed to,'' he said. The island, long used as an outdoor classroom for biology students from Rutgers University, Monmouth College, Brookdale Community College and local high schools, also is the site of a statesponsored clam relay program. Last year, 860,000 hard clams were transferred from the mildly polluted waters of the Shark River to Barnegat Bay, where they purified themselves in cleaner waters and later were marketed.
